The water meter deposit shall be as established from time to time by resolution of the city council. Water meter deposits are refundable upon separation from the city's water and sewer system. The final billing for water and/or sewer consumption will be paid from the deposit held on account, and the remaining balance of the deposit will be refunded to the customer. (Code 1979, § 20-106; Ord. of 6-1-09(2)) Sec. 82-61. - Service line regulations. (a) Limited to one building. No more than one building shall be permitted to use a water service line. (b) Piping. Only galvanized pipe shall be used for the installation of a service line. (c) Depth. All service lines shall be installed at a depth of at least 40 inches below the surface of the ground. (d) Stopcock and wastecock. Each service line shall contain a stopcock and wastecock where water may be turned on at the entrance of the water service pipe into the building. (e) Shutoff valves. In all buildings other than dwellings, shutoff valves shall be installed which permit the water supply to all equipment in each separate room to be shut off without interfering with the water supply to any other room or portion of the building. All apartment complexes shall have a shutoff valve for each apartment. (f) Compliance with plumbing code. All water connection installations shall comply with the city's plumbing code. (Code 1979, § 20-107) Secs. 82-62—82-80. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - WATER SERVICE CHARGES
Sec. 82-81. - Water rates. Water service rates shall be as established from time to time by resolution of the city council. (Code 1979, § 20-111) Secs. 82-82—82-105. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - CROSS CONNECTIONS
Sec. 82-106. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Auxiliary intake means any piping connection or other device whereby water may be secured from a source other than the source normally used. Bypass means any system of piping or other arrangement whereby the water may be diverted around any part or portion of a water purification plant. Cross connection means any physical connection whereby the public water supply is connected with any other water supply system, whether public or private, either inside or outside of any building, in such a manner that a flow of water into the public water supply is possible either through the manipulation of valves or because of ineffective check or back-pressure valves, or because of any other arrangement. Interconnection means any system of piping or other arrangement whereby the public water supply is connected directly with a sewer, drain, conduit, pool, storage reservoir, or other device which does or may contain sewage or other waste or liquid which would be capable of impacting or cause contamination to the public water supply. Public water supply means the waterworks system furnishing water to the city for general use and which supply is recognized as the public water supply by the Georgia Department of Natural Resources, Environmental Protection Division. (Code 1979, § 23-1) Sec. 82-107. - Determination of necessity for backflow prevention device. The building official shall be responsible for the protection of the public potable water distribution system from contamination or pollution due to the backflow of contaminants or pollutants through the water service connection. If, in the judgment of the building official an approved backflow prevention device is required at the customer's water service connection for the safety of the water system, the building official shall give notice, in writing, to the customer that installation of the device is required. Sec. 82-108. - Cross connection prohibited. (a) No water service connection to any premises shall be installed or maintained by the city unless the water supply is protected as required by state and federal laws and regulations and this division. Service of water to any premises shall be discontinued by the city if a backflow prevention device required by this division and state law is not installed, tested and maintained, or if it is found that a backflow prevention device has been removed or bypassed, or if an unprotected cross connection exists on the premises. Service will not be restored until such conditions or defects are corrected. Applicable requirements for backflow prevention will be complied with, prior to service connection. (b) When cross connections are found to exist, the owner, his agent, occupant, or tenant will be notified in writing to disconnect the cross connection within the time limit established by the City of Jasper. Degree of protection required and maximum time allowed for compliance will be based upon the potential degree of hazard to the public water supply system. The maximum time limits are as follows: (1) Cross connections with private wells or other auziliary water supplies - immediate disconnection. (2) All facilities which pose a health hazard to the potable water system must have a containment assembly in the form of a reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly within 60 days. (3) All industrial and non-residential facilities not identified as a health hazard shall be considered non-health hazard facilities. All non-health hazard facilities must install, as a minimum containment assembly, double check valve assembly within 90 days unless otherwise approved by the City of Jasper. (4) If, in the judgment of the City of Jasper, an imminent health hazard exists, water service to the building or premises where a cross connection exists may be terminated unless an air gap is immediately provided, or the cross connection is immediately eliminated. (5) Lawn irrigation systems are required to have a split tap service or designated lawn irrigation service tap. The connection of a lawn irrigation system to the service line at any point after the point of delivery is prohibited. (6) Based upon recommendation from the City of Jasper, the consumer is responsible for installing sufficient internal isolation backflow prevention assemblies and/or methods in example (air gap, pressure vacuum breakers, reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly, double check valve assembly). (7) Water mains served by the city but not maintained by the City of Jasper should be considered cross connections, with degree of hazard to be determined by the City of Jasper. Degree of protection shall be based upon the degree of hazard, as determined by the City of Jasper. (8) In the event that a City of Jasper cross connection control inspector does not have sufficient access to every portion of a private water system to allow a complete evaluation of the degree of hazard associated with the particular private water system, as approved reduced pressure principle assembly shall be required as a minimum of protection. (9) Customers shall not modify their private water system in a manner that would affect the degree of hazard of such system until the City of Jasper has been provided with information showing that the appropriate backflow prevention assembly is installed. If such modification or change determined by the City of Jasper to require the installation of a different backflow prevention assembly, the required backflow prevention assembly must be installed in accordance with provision of this division prior to making the proposed modification or change. (10) No person shall fill special use tanks or tankers containing pesticides, fertilizers, other toxic chemicals or their residues from the public water system except at a location equipped with an air gap or an approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly properly installed on the public water supply. ( Ord. of 4-7-2014 ) Sec. 82-109. - Inspection; disconnection of service. (a) The customer's system shall be open for inspection at all reasonable times to the building official or authorized representatives of the building official to determine whether cross connections or other structural or sanitary hazards, including violations of these regulations, exist. The frequency of inspections and reinspections based on potential health hazards involved shall be as established by the city's water and wastewater department. (b) When such a condition becomes known, the building official shall deny or immediately discontinue service to the premises by providing for a physical break in the service line until the customer has corrected the conditions in conformance with state and city statutes and ordinances relating to plumbing and water supplies and the regulations adopted pursuant thereto. The costs of installation of backflow prevention devices shall be borne by the consumer. (c) On request, the owner, lessee, or occupant of any property served by the city's water system shall furnish to the city or its designees any pertinent information regarding the piping system on such property. The refusal to provide information or refusal of access, when requested, shall be deemed evidence of the presence of cross connections. (Code 1979, § 23-6) Sec. 82-110. - Statement of no interconnection required. Any person whose premises are supplied with water from the public water supply, and who also has on the same premises a separate source of water supply or stores water in an uncovered or unsanitary storage reservoir from which the water stored therein is circulated through a piping system, shall file with the city a statement of the nonexistence of unproved or interconnections. The statement shall also contain an agreement that no cross connection, auxiliary intake, bypass, or interconnection will be permitted upon the premises. (Code 1979, § 23-4) Sec. 82-111. - Periodic inspection, testing, and repair of protective devices. (a) The city's water and wastewater department shall have the right to inspect and test all backflow prevention devices at least annually or more frequently if deemed necessary by the department. Water service shall not be disrupted to test the device without the knowledge of the occupant on the premises. (b) If use of water is critical to the continuance of normal operations or protection of life, property, or equipment, duplicate protective devices shall be provided to avoid the necessity of discontinuing water service for testing or repair. (c) If only one unit is installed and the continuance of service is critical, the department shall notify the occupant of the premises, in writing, of plans to discontinue water service and arrange for a mutually acceptable time to test or repair the device. (d) If the device is found to be defective, the department shall notify the occupant, in writing. The occupant or owner of the premises shall make all repairs indicated promptly, and the expense of such repairs shall be borne by the owner or occupant. Repairs shall be made by qualified personnel, acceptable to the city. Secs. 82-112—82-135. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - WATER CONSERVATION Subdivision I. - In General
Sec. 82-136. - Waste prohibited. Consumers shall prevent unnecessary waste of water and keep all water outlets closed when not in actual use. Hydrants, urinals, water closets, bathtubs, and other fixtures must not be left running for any purpose other than the use for which they were intended. When any such waste occurs, the water service may be terminated. (Code 1979, § 20-108) Sec. 82-137. - Irrigation or sprinkler restrictions. In case of water shortage or scarcity, the mayor and council may by resolution place any restrictions upon the use of water for irrigation or sprinkler purposes which such body deems necessary. (Code 1979, § 20-109) Sec. 82-138. - Water use during fire alarms. During all fire alarms, the use by persons other than city firefighters of hoses and other apparatus maintaining a constant flow of water is absolutely forbidden. (Code 1979, § 20-110) Secs. 82-139—82-159. - Reserved. Subdivision II. - Emergency Water Restrictions
Sec. 82-160. - Authority and purpose. The city, under its powers pursuant to state law, has adopted this subdivision to protect the public health and welfare. This subdivision implements the city's authority to impose water use restrictions, conditioned upon a restricted water use period declared by the city pursuant to the terms of this subdivision or a declared drought response level implementation declared by the state pursuant to chapter 391-3-30 of the Rules of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources, Environmental Protection Division, entitled Outdoor Water Use (Ga. Comp. Rules and Regs. 391-3-30-.01 et seq.) Sec. 82-161. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subdivision, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Address means the house number (a numeric or alphanumeric designation) that, together with the street name, describes a physical location of a specific property. Declared drought response level (DDRL) means one of four levels of drought that may be declared by the state department of natural resources based on the severity of drought conditions, with one being the least severe and four being the most severe, as provided in Ga. Comp. Rules and Regs. 391-3-30-.01 et seq., pertaining to outdoor water use. Even-numbered address means a house number ending with the number 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, or no house number. Odd-numbered address means a house number ending with the number 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9. Outdoor watering means any watering of decorative lawns, trees or shrubbery by water users. Water users means all persons or municipalities using water from any public water source irrespective of that person's responsibility for billing purposes for use of the water. Sec. 82-162. - Declaration of period of restricted water use. The mayor or city manager shall declare a period of restricted water use in either of two circumstances: (1) State DDRL announcement. In the event of imposition by the state department of natural resources of a DDRL encompassing the geographical area of the city or any part thereof, the mayor or city manager shall declare a water emergency and the level thereof. Upon the declaration, the restrictions of this subdivision shall apply to all water use within the city until the restrictions are lifted by the mayor or the city council; provided, however, that the restrictions shall remain in full force and effect until any state outdoor watering ban has been lifted. (2) Local declaration. In the event of prolonged drought, failure of equipment, or any other factor that substantially affects or may affect the supply of water to the city and the city's water users, the mayor or city manager may declare an emergency and the level thereof. Upon the declaration, the restrictions of this subdivision shall apply to all water use within the city until the restrictions are lifted. The declaration should be, where appropriate, conditioned on the identification of an emergency or water shortage by the city personnel, county personnel, state agency, federal agency, or the state governor. Sec. 82-163. - Notice of declaration. Upon declaration of a period of restricted water use, the mayor or city manager shall notify all users through news releases to the media, through notices mailed to all users, or through such other means as the mayor or city manager shall deem expedient and appropriate. Notice shall be given as soon as practical after the declaration of a period of restricted water use is made. Sec. 82-164. - Watering methods. During a period of restricted water use of any level, outdoor watering is restricted to bucket, can or handheld hose watering with automatic shutoff nozzle. The use of automatic sprinkler systems is prohibited, except watering of newly installed landscaping as permitted herein and except testing of a newly installed or newly repaired sprinkler system by a commercial enterprise engaged in the installation or repair of lawn irrigation systems. Sec. 82-165. - Level one restrictions. In the event of declaration of a level one period of restricted water use, the following restrictions shall apply within the city: (1) Outdoor water use may occur on scheduled days within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. to 12:00 midnight. (2) Scheduled days for oddnumbered addresses are Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays. (3) Scheduled days for evennumbered addresses are Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays. (4) Use of hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety or flushing is prohibited. Sec. 82-166. - Level two restrictions. In the event of declaration of a level two period of restricted water use, the following restrictions shall apply within the city: (1) Outdoor water use may occur on scheduled days within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. (2) Scheduled days for oddnumbered addresses are Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays. (3) Scheduled days for evennumbered addresses and golf course fairways are Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays. (4) The following uses are prohibited: a. Using hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety or flushing. b. Washing hard surfaces, such as streets, gutters, sidewalks and driveways except when necessary for public health and safety. Sec. 82-167. - Level three restrictions. In the event of declaration of a level three period of restricted water use, the following restrictions shall apply within the city: (1) Outdoor water use may occur on the scheduled day within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. (2) The scheduled day for oddnumbered addresses is Sunday. (3) The scheduled day for evennumbered addresses and golf course fairways is Saturday. (4) The following uses are prohibited: a. Using hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety or flushing. b. Washing hard surfaces, such as streets, gutters, sidewalks, driveways, except when necessary for public health and safety. c. Filling installed swimming pools except when necessary for health care or structural integrity. d. Washing vehicles, such as cars, boats, trailers, motorbikes, airplanes, golf carts. e. Washing buildings or structures except for immediate fire protection. f. Noncommercial fundraisers, such as carwashes. g. Using water for ornamental purposes, such as fountains, reflecting pools, and waterfalls except when necessary to support aquatic life. Sec. 82-168. - Level four restrictions. In the event of declaration of a level four period of restricted water use, no outdoor water use is permitted, unless the use is exempted under the provisions of this subdivision or specifically by the mayor or city manager. Sec. 82-169. - Exemptions. The following uses are exempt from the use restrictions of this subdivision unless the mayor or city manager, at the time of declaration of a period of restricted water use, shall specifically designate one or more of the exemptions inapplicable, and provided that in exercising an exemption water use conservation practices should be implemented wherever possible: (1) Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or stormwater in compliance with applicable provisions of this Code and any technical code adopted by the city; (2) Reuse of graywater in compliance with applicable provisions of this Code and any technical codes adopted by the city; (3) Use of reclaimed wastewater for landscaping purposes by a designated user from a system permitted by EPD to provide reclaimed wastewater; (4) Irrigation of personal food gardens; (5) Except during level four restrictions, irrigation of landscapes that have been installed for less than 30 days and by persons who are not certified or licensed professionals, any day of the week, but only during allowed hours for the restriction level in effect, and then only for a period of 30 days following installation; (6) For golf courses, use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by EPD to provide reclaimed wastewater, irrigation of fairways during times of nondrought and level one restrictions, irrigation of tees during times of nondrought and level one, two or three restrictions, and irrigation of greens; (7) Professionally certified or licensed landscapers, golf course contractors, and sports turf landscapers, but during installation and 30 days following installation only; (8) Irrigation contractors, but during installation and as needed for proper maintenance and adjustments only; (9) Sod producers, ornamental growers, fruit and vegetable growers, retail garden center, hydroseeding, powerwashing, construction sites, producers of food and fiber, carwashes; (10) Water in of pesticides and herbicides on turf; (11) Use of water for firefighting, health, sanitation, and medical purposes; and (12) Other activities essential to daily business. Sec. 82-170. - Application for waiver. Any water user that considers the restrictions imposed during a period of restricted water use to adversely affect their livelihood, health or sanitation, may make written application for a waiver. Any such application should be directed to the attention of the mayor or city manager who shall make a determination regarding waiver within five business days of receipt of the application. The determination of the mayor or city manager shall be final. Sec. 82-171. - Issuance of written warnings to violators. Persons violating water use restrictions as provided herein shall be given one warning in writing prior to the issuance of a citation, unless: (1) The period of restricted water use is declared in response to a DDRL imposed by the state and applicable in the geographical limits of the city; or (2) The declaration of a period of restricted water use specifically provides that no warnings will be given. Sec. 82-172. - Penalties. Any person violating the provisions of this subdivision shall be liable to the municipality in the amount of up to $100.00 for the first violation and up to $1,000.00 for the second violation. Third and subsequent violations shall be subject to a fine of up to $1,000.00 and imprisonment for a period of up to 90 days. In addition, third and subsequent violations may, at the discretion of the city, result in immediate shut off of water service for such period as is deemed expedient and necessary under the circumstances, with approval of the city council. Secs. 82-173—82-197. - Reserved. DIVISION 6. - WELLHEAD PROTECTION
Sec. 82-198. - Purpose and intent. The purpose of this division is to ensure the provisions of a safe and sanitary drinking water supply for the city by establishment of wellhead protection zones surrounding the wellheads for all wells or springs which are the supply sources for the city water system and by the designation and regulation of property uses and conditions which may be maintained within such zones. Sec. 82-199. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Hazardous waste or hazardous material means any waste or material which because of its quantity, concentration or physical, chemical or infectious characteristics may: (1) Cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitation reversible illness; or (2) Pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or to the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed of or otherwise managed. Sanitary landfill means a disposal site where solid wastes, including putrescible wastes, or hazardous wastes, are disposed of on land by placing earth cover thereon. Wellhead means the upper terminal of a well, including adapters, ports, seals, valves and other attachments. Sec. 82-200. - Establishment of zone. The city has established a use district to be known as a wellhead protection zone, identified and described as all the area within a circle, the center of which is the center of any city water supply wellhead and the radius of which is 250 feet. Sec. 82-201. - Permitted uses. The following uses shall be permitted within wellhead protection zones: (1) Any use permitted within existing agricultural or single-family residential districts, except that the minimum residential lot size for a lot, any portion of which lies within the wellhead protection zone, shall not be less one acre; and (2) Any other open land use where any building located on the property is incidental and accessory to the primary open land use. Sec. 82-202. - Prohibited uses. The following uses or conditions shall be and are hereby prohibited within wellhead protection zones, regardless of whether the use or condition may otherwise be ordinarily included as a part of a use permitted herein: (1) Surface use or storage of hazardous material, expressly including commercial use of agricultural pesticides; (2) Septic tanks or drainfields appurtenant thereto; (3) Impervious surfaces other than roofs of buildings, and streets, driveways and walks serving buildings permitted hereunder; (4) Sanitary landfills; (5) Hazardous waste disposal sites; (6) Stormwater infiltration basins; (7) Underground storage tanks; (8) Sanitary sewer lines within 150 feet of a wellhead. Sec. 82-203. - Administration. The policies and procedures for administration of any wellhead protection zone established under this division, including without limitation those applicable to nonconforming uses, exceptions, enforcement and penalties, shall be the same as provided in chapter 94, pertaining to zoning, as the same is presently enacted or may from time to time be amended. Secs. 82-204—82-229. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - SEWERS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 82-230. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Authorized person means a regular employee of the water and wastewater department or its legal agent. Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures in five days at 20 degrees Celsius (expressed in milligrams per liter), or as otherwise defined in standard methods. Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes within the walls of a building and conveys such discharge to the building sewer beginning ten feet outside the inner face of the building. Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sanitary sewer or other place of disposal. Chemical oxygen demand (COD) means to the amount of oxygen equivalent to the organic matter in a sample utilized in the presence of a strong chemical oxidant (expressed in milligrams per liter), or as otherwise defined in standard methods. Combined sewer means a sewer receiving, intentionally groundwater, surface water, and stormwater together with sewage. Constituents means the combination of particles or pollutants which exist in wastes. Control manhole means a manhole on or near a customer's property used for sewage sampling purposes through which the customer's unique discharge to the sanitary sewer passes. Designated area means any tract of land, parcel of land, subdivision, or section of the city which by virtue of its topography or existing sanitary sewer facilities can be treated as a unit. The water and sewerage superintendent shall be the sole judge as to the boundaries, limits, and extents of such areas, whether or not these areas abut present public roads. Flammable means any material which is easily ignited and burns with unusual rapidity as defined by the National Fire Protection Association. Flush toilet means the common sanitary flush commode in general use for the disposal of human excrement. Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes, resulting from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and disposing of food; and from handling, storage and sale of produce, tin cans, glass containers, and newspapers. Industrial wastes means the liquid waste, of whatever nature, arising out of any manufacturing, processing, fabricating, treating, renovating, or any other commercial operation. Inspection fee means the amount of money charged to the contracting plumber for each inspection. Lot of land means the smallest unit, owned by the same party, into which any tract or parcel of land has been divided either by deed, plat, or any other means of subdivision. Objectionable means unacceptable, unsatisfactory, or displeasing to the physical senses. Outlet means point of discharge onto a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, stream, or other body of surface water or groundwater. ph means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration, measured as number of moles per liter, and expressed as a dimensionless number. Plumbing fee means that fee paid to the city for the issuance of a plumbing permit. Pollution means dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discarded equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt, industrial wastes, municipal waste and agricultural waste discharged into the waters of the state. The term "pollution" does not mean: (1) Sewage from vessels; or (2) Water, gas or other material which is injected into a well to facilitate production of oil or gas or water derived in association with oil or gas production and disposed of in a well, if the well, used either to facilitate production or for disposal purposes, is approved by the appropriate authorities of this state and if such authorities determine that such injection or disposal will not result in degradation of ground or surface water resources. Premises means a building, house, store, plant, or any other place where people live, work or congregate. Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of foods, which have been cut in such a way that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sanitary sewers, with no particle larger than one-half inch in any dimension. Public sewer means a common sanitary sewer directly controlled by the city. Sanitary sewer means a pipe which carries sewage and excludes groundwater, surface water and stormwater. Septic tank means a subsurface impervious tank designed to temporarily retain sewage or similar waterborne wastes together with: (1) A sewer line constructed with solid pipe, with the joints sealed, connecting the impervious tank with a plumbing stub-out; and (2) A subsurface system of trenches, piping, and other materials constructed to drain the clarified discharge from the tank and distribute it underground to be filtered or absorbed. Sewage means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, and institutions; together with such groundwater, surface water, or stormwater as may be present. Sewer means an artificial, usually subterranean, conduit to carry off sewage and sometimes surface water. Sewer tap fee means the service charge for making a connection to the sewerage system. Sewerage system and sewerage mean all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating, transporting, and disposing of sewage. Slug means any discharge of water, sewage, or industrial waste in which the concentration of any given constituent exceeds for any period longer than 15 minutes, five times the average 24-hour concentration of that constituent during normal operation. Standard methods refers to Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater, 21st Edition, 2005, published by APHA, AWWA, and WPCF. Storm drain or storm sewer means a sewer which carries stormwater and surface water and drainage, excluding sewage and industrial waste. Subdivision means any tract of land divided, planned or developed as a subdevelopment with two or more residences, buildings or building sites. Superintendent means the water and sewerage superintendent authorized by the city council to administer and enforce this article, and be responsible for the operation and maintenance of the water and wastewater system, or his agent. Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, sewage, or other liquids; and which are removable by laboratory filtering; or as otherwise defined in standard methods. Tap fee means the service charge for making a connection to the sewerage system. Unsanitary means unclean, unhealthy, or harmful to public health. Water pollution control plant means an arrangement of devices and structures used to treat sewage. Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. (Code 1979, § 21-101) Sec. 82-231. - Administration and enforcement. The construction, operation, and maintenance of all sanitary sewer lines under the city's jurisdiction is a responsibility of the water and wastewater department. All existing and future sanitary sewer lines laid in the city and all areas served by these sanitary sewer lines are within the jurisdiction of this department except those areas within the corporate limits of municipalities unless arranged by prior agreement or ordinance. The city council supervises all resources of the department to effectively carry out the responsibilities of constructing, operating, and maintaining the sanitary sewer system. (Code 1979, § 21-106.1) Sec. 82-232. - Discharge from outside city limits prohibited. No persons or governments residing or operating outside the limits of the city shall discharge or cause to be discharged any material into the sanitary sewer system of the city without the prior approval of the city council. (Code 1979, § 21-102.7) Sec. 82-233. - Authority of city to tax not impaired. Nothing in this article shall be construed as limiting the right of the city council to create, operate, and maintain the sewerage system through the imposition of ad valorem taxation. (Code 1979, § 21-102.6) Sec. 82-234. - Compliance with applicable usage agreement. The operation of the sanitary sewer system shall remain in compliance with all sanitary sewer usage agreements between the county and other governments and agencies. (Code 1979, § 21-106.2) Sec. 82-235. - Authority of inspectors to issue summons. The city council may designate authorized persons in the water and wastewater department to write summons to appear in the city court to answer questions pertaining to violations of this article. (Code 1979, § 21-108.1) Sec. 82-236. - Authority of inspectors to inspect certain properties. The clerk of the water and wastewater department and other employees designated by him, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall have the authority: (1) Industrial or commercial properties. To enter all commercial and industrial properties for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurements, sampling, and testing in accordance with the provisions of this article. The clerk or his designated agents shall have authority to inquire into processes only to the point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the waterways or sewerage system. Inquiries into the makeup or mechanism of the process are not authorized. (2) Private properties. To enter all private properties through which the city holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to measurement, maintenance, observation, repair, and sampling any portion of the sewage system lying within said easement. All entry and subsequent work on the easement shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the specific easement pertaining to the property involved. Specific permission is granted the clerk and his designated agents, upon proper notification, to enter all private properties for the purpose of surveying or inspecting the premises. While working on private properties referred to in this section all city employees shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises. The owner of said private properties shall not be held liable for injury to city employees while on his properties. (Code 1979, § 21-108.2, 21-108.3) Secs. 82-237—82-265. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - SEWER DISCHARGE REGULATIONS
Sec. 82-266. - Use of public sanitary sewers required. The owners of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, and other such purposes, located within the jurisdiction of the city, and abutting on any street, alley, or right-of-way in which there is now located a public sanitary sewer, is required to install at his expense suitable toilet facilities, and to connect such facilities directly to the public sanitary sewer; provided that said public sanitary sewer is within 100 feet of the property line. (Code 1979, § 21-103.1) Sec. 82-267. - Prohibited discharges. Unless specifically otherwise provided in this article or by ordinance of the city council it shall be unlawful to: (1) Construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other similar facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage within the city limits. (2) Discharge to any outlet or to any portion of the public storm drain system, within the jurisdiction of the city, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with provisions of this article. Nothing in this subsection should be construed to require the city to treat the outflow from the public storm drain system. (3) Place, deposit, or permit the deposit of, in an unsanitary manner, human or animal excrement, garbage, or objectionable wastes on any public or private property within the jurisdiction of the city. (4) Discharge to a public sanitary sewer of stormwater, surface water runoff, or groundwater is prohibited. Such waters shall be discharged to sewers specifically designated as storm sewers, or to an outlet approved by the city council. (5) Discharge to a public sanitary sewer of gasoline, benzene, naptha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquids, solids, or gases is prohibited. (6) Discharge to a public sanitary sewer of water wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids, or gases in a quantity sufficient to interfere, independently or via interaction with other substances, with any sewerage or sewage treatment process, or constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or make hazardous the receiving waters of sewage plant effluent. (7) Discharge to a public sanitary sewer of wastewater having a pH lower than 5.5 or higher than 9.5 or having corrosive properties capable of causing damage to sewerage or harm to personnel is prohibited. (8) Discharge to a public sanitary sewer of solids or viscous liquids in quantities, types or sizes causing either flow obstruction in sewers, or interference with the operation of the treatment facility, and discharge of solids or viscous liquids having a size of greater than one inch in any dimension, are prohibited. (9) Discharge materials or substances which would cause the effluent quality from sewage treatment plants to violate state or federal standards is prohibited. Included in this category, but not by way of limitation, are: a. Slug concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as lime slurries). b. Slug concentrations of inert dissolved solids (such as sodium chloride). c. Slug concentrations of colored wastes (such as dyes and tanning solutions). d. Slug concentrations of materials high in BOD or COD. e. Other wastes not amenable to treatment. (10) Discharge water or wastes containing taste or odor producing contaminants in such quantities that after treatment of sewage these contaminants impart their tastes or odors to receiving waters are prohibited. (11) Discharge water or wastes colored by dye or other such solutions to such a degree that the color is not removed by treatment. (12) Discharge wastes containing substances emitting radiation greater than 1,000 picocuries per liter (pCi/L) for gross beta, or three picocuries per liter (pCi/L) for Radium 226 and Strontium 90. (13) Discharge liquid or water vapor having a temperature greater than 150 degrees Fahrenheit is prohibited. (14) Discharge water or waste containing fats, wax, grease, or oils of a petroleum or mineral base, in a concentration greater than 100 mg/l is prohibited. (15) Discharge substances which become solids or very viscous liquids at temperatures greater than 32 degrees Fahrenheit are prohibited. (16) Discharge garbage that has been improperly shredded (any dimension greater than one-half inch). (17) Discharge waters or wastes containing the contaminants listed at a concentration greater than the limits set:
The limits listed in this subsection may be changed by the city council in the event of a cumulative overload on a particular drainage basin or sewage treatment plant. (18) Discharge any other contaminant which the city council deems harmful to the operation or efficiency of sewage treatment plants, or to the health and welfare of the residents of the city. (Code 1979, §§ 21-103.2—103.4, 21-105.1, 105.3—105.5) Sec. 82-268. - Discharges requiring pretreatment. (a) The city may require pretreatment of wastes to an acceptable condition before discharge to a public sanitary sewer when waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics of prohibited discharges. Such waters may have a deleterious effect upon sewerage, receiving waters, or any other aspects of public welfare. In addition to lowering the concentrations of substances to an acceptable level, or altering the characteristics of a waste, the city may require additional controls before discharge to the public sanitary sewer system. The limits of such discharges shall be as set forth herein. (b) Any customer who exceeds the maximum limits for such discharges as set forth herein must provide a schedule for compliance with said standards by pretreatment within two months of notification of noncompliance. Compliance with the standard pretreatment levels must be obtained within six months of notification of noncompliance. (Code 1979, § 21-105.8) Sec. 82-269. - Industrial discharges. (a) Industrial contributors to the public sanitary sewer system shall be required to pay a sewer rate surcharge based upon the concentration of suspended solids and five-day BOD in their effluents. Industrial dischargers whose wastes contain greater than 350 mg/l of either five-day BOD and/or suspended solids and a COD of 1,000 mg/l shall pay the surcharge in an amount set by the city council. (b) If values for five-day BOD or suspended solids exceed 350 mg/l, or if values for COD exceed 500 mg/l, then the council may, if it determines that these wastes adversely affect the operation of sewage treatment plants, require the owner to install pretreatment before he discharges wastes to the public sanitary sewer system. Such pretreatment must alter the condition of the discharge to the point where it no longer harms the operation of the sewage treatment plants and the values for both five-day BOD and suspended solids will be below 350 mg/l and values for COD will be below 1,000 mg/l. (c) Periodic determination of the values for five-day BOD, suspended solids and COD shall be made on composite samples of industrial fluids by personnel designated by the city. (Code 1979, § 21-105.7) Sec. 82-270. - Separators, interceptors, and traps. (a) Grease, oil, and sand separators shall be provided when wastes containing more than 100 mg/l of fat, oil, grease, or sand are discharged. Separators shall also be provided for any other substance in the wastes which becomes viscous or solidifies at a temperature above 32 degrees Fahrenheit. (b) All interceptors or separators shall be approved in writing by the city council and shall be located for easy inspection. All expenses of installation and operation shall be borne by the owner. Interceptors and separators shall not be required for private living quarters. (c) Water and sewer customers with grease traps shall limit the amount of fats, oils and greases to 350 mg/l when leaving their systems and entering into the city's sewer system. (Code 1979, §§ 21-105.6, 21-109.1; Ord. No. 21-109.1(a), 5-7-2007) Sec. 82-271. - Measurements, tests, and analyses. (a) All measurements, tests, and analyses of wastes to which reference is made in this division shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of standard methods. Analyses shall be determined at the control manhole, or upon a suitable sample taken at the control manhole. In the event that no control manhole is available on the building sewer, then the control manhole shall be considered the nearest downstream manhole to which the building sewer is directly connected. When the city council deems it necessary, the owner of any property served by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole on the building sewer to facilitate observation and sampling of wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessible, safely located, and constructed at the owner's expense in accordance with city specifications. (b) Sampling shall be done by accepted methods in order to reflect the effect of contaminants on the sewerage system and the public health. The particular analyses involved dictate whether samples should be 24-hour composites or grab samples: (1) Composites: BOD suspended solids; (2) Grabs: pH, temperature. Determination of which type sample to take shall be governed by recommended sampling procedures in the standard methods. (Code 1979, § 21-105.9) Sec. 82-272. - Accidental spill or drain of deleterious material. In the event of an accidental spill or an unavoidable loss to the drains of any deleterious material or substances, the person concerned shall promptly inform the city water and wastewater department of the nature, quantity and time of occurrence of the spill. The person concerned shall take all possible actions to prevent a spill, and should a spill occur shall take immediate steps to ensure no reoccurrence of the spill. Where there exists an approved drain to the sanitary sewer in an area where there is the potential for a leak or spill of toxic or flammable material, an emergency block valve on the sanitary sewer downstream of the affected drain shall be required. (Code 1979, § 21-105.11) Sec. 82-273. - Special industrial agreements. Nothing contained in this division shall be construed as preventing a special agreement between the city and an industrial concern whereby a waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city water and wastewater department for treatment. (Code 1979, § 21-105.10) Sec. 82-274. - Hauled wastewater. (a) Septic tank waste may be introduced into the wastewater treatment plant at locations designated by the city and at such times as established by the city. Such waste shall not violate any section of this article. The city may require septic tank waste haulers to obtain a wastewater discharge permit. A fee for disposal of septic tank waste shall be charged according to a schedule of adopted by the mayor and council. (b) Hauled industrial waste may be introduced into the wastewater treatment plant at locations designated by the city, at such times as established by the city and after approval is granted by the city. Such waste shall not violate any section of this article. The city may require the waste hauler to obtain a wastewater discharge permit if the total daily wastewater discharged exceeds 25,000 gallons per day. The city may require the industrial waste hauler to provide a waste analysis of any load prior to discharge. The city may collect samples of each hauled load to ensure compliance with applicable standards. A fee for disposal of hauled industrial waste shall be charged according to a schedule adopted by the mayor and council. (Ord. of 5-3-2010(1)) Secs. 82-275—82-294. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - SEWER CHARGES
Sec. 82-295. - Rates levied. (a) A service charge shall be levied and assessed for the operation and maintenance of the sewerage system based on the amount of potable water consumed per month by each contributor to the sewerage system. The rate at which this charge is levied shall be as approved and adopted from time to time by resolution of the city council. (b) A readiness-to-serve charge is imposed for the operation of the sewerage system based on the size of the customer's water meter. A surcharge for over-strength waste (i.e., wastes consisting of suspended solids or biochemical oxygen demand materials in concentrations exceeding 200 mg/l, and COD materials in concentrations exceeding 500 mg/l) is levied at a rate approved and adopted from time to time by resolution of the city council. (Code 1979, § 21-102.1) Secs. 82-296—82-323. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - PRIVATE SEWAGE SYSTEMS
Sec. 82-324. - Nonavailability of sanitary sewer. (a) If a public sanitary sewer is not available, as determined by the city water and wastewater department, the building sewer shall be connected to another means of sewage disposal. (b) The private sewage disposal system must comply with all applicable regulations of the city's water and wastewater department, the county health department, the Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources, and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. Unless specific exceptions are made, a private sewage disposal facility in the city shall consist of an approved septic tank. (c) Applications for installation and use of septic tank systems shall be made as provided in this division. Other types of private sewage disposal systems as may be approved by the city shall comply with all listed requirements of this article regarding permit application, operation, and eventual connection to a public sanitary sewer. (Code 1979, § 21-103.5) Sec. 82-325. - Septic tank systems. (a) Applications for a septic tank usage permit shall be made to the county health department accompanied with a set of plans, topographic sketches, percolation tests, rock borings and other data as deemed necessary by the health department. Copies of the application shall be forwarded to the city water and wastewater department for comments and approval. A fee shall be payable to the city at the time the application is made in an amount set by the city. (b) The owner of the septic tank shall bear all operation and maintenance expenses incident to a sanitary operation. (c) At such time as a public sanitary sewer becomes available to property served by a septic tank, provided that said public sanitary sewer is within 100 feet of the property line, a direct connection in compliance with other sections of this article shall be made. This connection shall be made within 24 months of the receipt of notice of availability of the public sanitary sewer for all properties of less than one acre of land. (d) All abandoned septic tanks shall be filled with clean-run gravel or suitable substitute material at the expense of the property owner. (Code 1979, § 21-103.5) Secs. 82-326—82-353. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - PRIVATE SEWER LINES
Sec. 82-354. - Connection of private sewers to the public system. Whenever a private sanitary sewer line, whether truck or lateral, which services private residences or businesses, is to be connected into the city sewerage system, a hearing must be held before the city council before assessing each abutting property owner for a sewer tap fee. Notice shall be given to the affected property owners of the time and place of this hearing at least 20 days prior. The clerk of the water and wastewater department shall comply with the intent of this section by mailing all notices to the appropriate owners listed on the latest ad valorem tax digest of the county at the addresses indicated. Records of the water and wastewater department indicating the mailing of notices shall be prima facie evidence and failure of the owner of any property concerned to receive his notice shall in no way affect the validity of either the meeting or the assessments. If the property owners abutting the private sanitary sewer desire immediate connection and consent to paying the appropriate fees and assessments, then the connection shall be made without the necessity of a notice or a hearing. (Code 1979, § 21-107.1) Sec. 82-355. - Public hearing regarding connection of private sewer. At the hearing for the connection of the private sanitary sewer into the city sewerage system any person whose property or interests are affected may appear before the city council in person or through his agent or attorney. The city council shall determine whether or not the connection sought will provide a necessary service, and if the public welfare will profit from it. All evidence either in support or objection to the connection will be heard. The city council's decision shall be final and conclusive, and all fees or assessments levied against the abutting property owners as a result of the decision shall be legal and binding. (Code 1979, § 21-107.2) Sec. 82-356. - Application for refund of construction costs. Whenever a person provides service to his own property by constructing a sanitary sewer line along any public road in the city or county, then if he desires cost refunds he must file an itemized cost sheet with the water and wastewater department. Then if property owners abutting this sanitary sewer desire connection within 25 years after constructing, provided they have not previously contributed to the sanitary sewer costs, the city may assess them on a prorated basis to recover expenditures. At the time the cost sheet is filed, the clerk of the water and wastewater department shall be responsible to ensure that all itemized values do not exceed the amount currently paid by the county for similar construction. If a cost sheet is not filed within six months after the completion, the city shall be relieved of any responsibility to collect from abutting property owners who desire future connection. All monies collected shall be refunded to the person, his successors, heirs, or assignees who constructed the original line. If the clerk cannot locate the person, his successors, heirs, or assignees after five years he may remit funds collected to the water and sewer fund. (Code 1979, § 21-107.3) Secs. 82-357—82-385. - Reserved. DIVISION 6. - SEWER CONNECTIONS
Sec. 82-386. - Prohibited connections. (a) It is illegal to connect to the public sanitary sewer without payment of the prescribed fee and without a permit. In the event such a sewer connection is made, a current sewer tap fee, the fee at the time the connection was discovered, will be assessed, back sewer use charges will be made, and interest at the legal rate on money due the city will be charged as directed by the city council. (b) Connection directly or indirectly of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, area drains, or other sources of surface runoff is not permitted to a building drain or building sewer connected to a public sanitary sewer. Existing connections of such items to a building sewer shall be disconnected when the building sewer is connected to the public sanitary sewer system. (Code 1979, §§ 21-104.8, 21-104.9) Sec. 82-387. - New separate connections required; exception. A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building. An exception is made where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sanitary sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, courtyard, or driveway; then the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole system considered one building sewer. Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, upon examination and test by the clerk of the water and wastewater department, to meet all requirements of this article. (Code 1979, § 21-104.2) Sec. 82-388. - Conformity with city specifications required. The size, slope, alignment, and materials used in constructing a building sewer; the methods used in excavating, placing the pipe, and backfilling of the trench; and the testing of the pipe shall all conform to the specifications and guidelines of the city council and other applicable rules of the city council. The connection of the building sewer into the public sanitary sewer shall conform to the requirements of the city council. All connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from specified procedures must be approved in writing by the city council. (Code 1979, § 21-104) Sec. 82-389. - Elevation techniques for gravity flow. Unless otherwise authorized in writing by the city council, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which a building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sanitary sewer, sewage carried by this drain shall be lifted by an approved sewage ejector to a height to permit gravity flow. All sewage ejector installations shall be approved by the city council. (Code 1979, § 21-104.4) Sec. 82-390. - Expenses of connection. The owner shall bear all costs and expenses incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer. The owner shall compensate the city for any loss or damage that may have occurred to the public sanitary sewer as a result of the installation of the building sewer. (Code 1979, § 21-104.5) Sec. 82-391. - Excavations; restoration of public property. Excavations necessary for the accomplishment of the connection shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights, so as to protect the public from hazard. All excavations greater than five feet deep shall be covered when excavation is not being conducted. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of work, shall be restored at the owner's expense, in compliance with the city council's specifications. (Code 1979, § 21-104.7) Sec. 82-392. - Permit required for connection or alteration. No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or open, use, alter or disturb any public sanitary sewer or appurtenance, without first obtaining a written permit from the water and wastewater department. (Code 1979, § 21-105.2) Sec. 82-393. - Application for building permit. (a) Applications for building sewer permits shall be supplemented by plans, specifications, and other information considered pertinent to the issuance of a permit. At the time the application is filed, a plumbing and inspection fee in an amount currently set by the city council shall be paid to the clerk of the water and wastewater department. Installations and their respective tapping fees, as set by the city council, shall be placed in one of the two categories, residential or nonresidential. (b) An applicant for a building sewer permit shall notify the clerk of the water and wastewater department when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sanitary sewer. (c) Service shall not be instituted until the plumbing fee and sewer tap fee are paid and the connection is approved. (Code 1979, § 21-104.1, 21-104.7) Secs. 82-394—82-414. - Reserved. DIVISION 7. - CONSTRUCTION OF SANITARY SEWER FACILITIES
Sec. 82-415. - Petition for construction; exception. Whenever the owners, as listed on the latest ad valorem tax digest, of more than 51 percent of the property within any designated area petition the city for sewer facilities that would require the laying of a lateral sewer, the petition shall be filed with the city council. The petition shall be examined to see if the signatures are valid and if it sufficiently describes the services required. If not, the petition shall be returned to the filing persons for correction. (Code 1979, § 21-106.3) Sec. 82-416. - Procedure. (a) When a petition for the construction of a sanitary sewer line has been filed on behalf of a person, or when a recommendation for construction has been made by the head of any board or department of the city, then a public hearing must be held before the city council. (b) The clerk of the water and wastewater department shall notify the city council of the impending petition. He shall then give notice to all persons concerned by publication of a notice in the newspaper where sheriff's notices are published for a period of at least 20 days prior to the hearing. The notice shall state the date and location of the proposed public hearing and shall give a general description of the proposed sanitary sewer construction. (c) When the clerk of the water and wastewater department has received the plans, specifications, and necessary engineering data with regard to an application for construction of sewer facilities, he shall determine the names of all property owners affected and procure the necessary right-of-way for construction of the sanitary sewer line as specified. Before final approval of any plans he must also ensure that sufficient stub-out connections are designated to adequately serve the territory affected. (d) All owners of property abutting the proposed sanitary sewer line who shall be assessed for the cost of construction shall be notified in writing by the clerk of the water and wastewater department at least 20 days prior to the hearing. The clerk shall comply with the intent of this section by addressing all notices to the owners listed on the latest ad valorem tax digest of the county at the addresses indicated. The records of the water and wastewater department showing evidence of the mailing of these notices shall be prima facie evidence, and failure of the owner of any property concerned to receive his notice shall in no way affect the validity of the proceedings or the assessment. (e) At the hearing provided for in this procedure any person whose property or interests are affected by the proposed sanitary sewer may appear before the city council either in person or through his agent or attorney. All evidence relevant to the question, whether in support or in objection, may be presented. (f) The decision of the city council with respect to the approval or rejection of the proposed sanitary sewer shall be final and conclusive. Any decision by the city council in favor of the construction shall indicate a public need for the sanitary sewer, and this shall make all matters pertaining to the construction of the sanitary sewer and the assessment of costs against the abutting property owners legal and binding. (Code 1979, §§ 21-106.5—21-106-7, 21-106.9) Sec. 82-417. - Exception; county recommended construction. When the county health department or any other county agency recommends to the city council the laying of any lateral or truck sanitary sewer for reasons of public sanitation, the city council may act on its own to order the construction of the necessary sanitary sewer. In such cases, assessment of cost against the property owners shall be made as if more than 51 percent or more of the affected property owners had consented, in writing. All owners of property abutting the proposed sanitary sewer line who shall be assessed for the cost of construction shall be notified, in writing, by the clerk of the water and wastewater department at least 20 days prior to the hearing. The clerk shall comply with the intent of this section by addressing all notices to the owners listed on the latest ad valorem tax digest of the city at the addresses indicated. (Code 1979, § 21-106.8) Sec. 82-418. - Persons authorized to perform construction. All sanitary sewers shall be constructed by the water and wastewater department or by such contractors as the city council may designate from time to time. Construction shall be under the supervision of the clerk of the water and wastewater department. (Code 1979, § 21-106.10) Secs. 82-419—82-449. - Reserved. DIVISION 8. - ASSESSMENTS FOR SEWER CONSTRUCTION
Sec. 82-450. - Clerk to make up assessment roll; calculations. (a) After the construction of a sanitary sewer line has been completed, the clerk of the water and wastewater department shall make up an assessment roll properly describing the sanitary sewer line and containing the names of all owners of abutting property. Each owner's property abutting the sanitary sewer shall be correctly described as it pertains to the construction. (b) The cost of the sanitary sewer line shall be shared among the various property owners on a prorated basis depending on the number of linear feet each has abutting the sanitary sewer line. (c) The actual assessment shall be calculated using a value in dollars and cents per linear foot based on the average cost for construction of all petitioned sanitary sewer lines in the city the previous year. (d) The minimum assessment shall be for 65 feet whether or not a sanitary sewer line has to extend that distance to serve a property or not. (Code 1979, § 21-106.11) Sec. 82-451. - Certain specific computations. (a) Whenever a tract of land abuts a sanitary sewer line on both the front and the rear, and the tract of land cannot be subdivided into two or more separate lots fronting each of the abutting sewers, then the property shall be assessed only for the side with the greater frontage. (b) Several considerations shall be made before determining whether or not a tract of land can be subdivided. If the topography of the land makes it impractical to construct a building on one of the lots, or to provide sanitary sewer service to one of the lots, then the tract of land is not suitable for subdivision. (c) Property owners who have contributed to the cost of existing sanitary sewers, whether by private contract, the original subdivision, or previous city assessment shall be exempted from current assessment. However, if property owners or previous owners did not contribute to the construction cost of existing sanitary sewers, they shall be assessed in the same manner as any other abutting property owner. (Code 1979, § 21-106.12) Sec. 82-452. - Assessment of corner property. Corner properties shall be assessed in the following manner: (1) Where the sanitary sewer abuts the property only on the front, the property shall be assessed for the amount of frontage. (2) Where the sanitary sewer abuts the property on both the front and side, the property shall be assessed for the frontage; the first 150 feet of the side abutting shall be exempted from assessment; the next 100 feet of the side abutting shall be subject to assessment; and the remainder of the side abutting beyond 250 feet shall be treated as outfall sewer and not assessed. (3) Where the sanitary sewer abuts the property on the side only, the property shall be assessed for the frontage; the first 150 feet abutting on the sides shall be exempted; the next 100 feet of the sides abutting shall be subject to assessment; and the remainder of the side abutting beyond 250 feet shall be treated as outfall sewer and not assessed. (4) Where the sanitary sewer abuts property that is pie-shaped or has an unusual frontage and that frontage is greater than the largest normal shaped and assessed property, the property will be assessed for the same number of front feet as the largest, normal shaped assessable property in the petitioned area. The clerk shall have the responsibility for determining what properties are to be considered pie-shaped or unusual. (Code 1979, § 21-106.13) Sec. 82-453. - Exception for outfall sewers. An outfall sewer is defined to be a section of sanitary sewer line, either in a public street or across private property, which normally does not provide direct service to the abutting property. Usually the outfall sewer is a section of a trunk sewer providing service to several street sanitary sewers serving properties. The cost of constructing an outfall sewer cannot be assessed against the abutting property owners; all expenses for laying and constructing this sanitary sewer shall be borne by the city. (Code 1979, § 21-106.14) Sec. 82-454. - No exception for board of education. Whenever property owned by the board of education abuts a section of sanitary sewer line, such property shall not be exempted from assessment. (Code 1979, § 21-106.15) Sec. 82-455. - Payment of assessments. (a) Whenever a sanitary sewer line has been constructed in accordance with this article and the cost thereof has been assessed against the benefiting property, the respective owners shall be notified of the assessment and they shall be required to pay in cash within 60 days to the city the amount of the assessment. (b) If the amount of the assessment causes a financial burden on the owner, then he may extend the assessment and pay it in annual installments. However, no less than one-fifth of the total assessment shall be paid within 60 days after notification. (Code 1979, § 21-106.16) Sec. 82-456. - Payment extension agreements. (a) If the property owner requires an extension in the payment of his assessment, then he must execute in writing an extension agreement with the city council stating that he shall pay a 20 percent down payment and the remainder of the assessment in a maximum of four equal annual installments. (b) The extension agreement must be executed on or before the due date of the assessment. (c) In the agreement, the owner must acknowledge that throughout the term of the extension the assessment remains legal and valid, and all liens remain in force. (d) The unpaid portion of the assessment shall bear current interest charges from the due date in the amount determined by resolution of the city council, and each annual installment shall include the portion of the assessment due and all interest accumulated through the date of payment of the installment. (e) The agreement shall be negotiable in form, and the city shall reserve the right to transfer or assign it to third parties. (f) If ever the owner defaults in the payment of any installment, then the entire assessment shall immediately become due and payable. (Code 1979, § 21-106.17) Sec. 82-457. - Assessments as liens against property. All assessments against property and the owners thereof for sanitary sewer construction shall be liens upon the property from the date the city council adopts the resolution authorizing construction. All assessments shall be posted in an improvement docket and kept on file in the water and wastewater department. Properties assessed shall be described in the docket in a manner sufficient to identify them with the section of the sanitary sewer they abut. (Code 1979, § 21-106.19) Sec. 82-458. - Failure to pay assessment. Should the owner of any property against which a sanitary sewer assessment has been levied fail to pay the assessment in cash within 60 days or to execute and timely pay an extension agreement as provided herein plus interest, then an execution shall be issued in rem against the property and in personam against the owner in the name of the city council. The execution shall be recorded on the general execution docket in the office of the clerk of the superior court and shall include sums to cover principal, interest, and administrative costs. All adjoining property owned by the same party or parties shall be covered in the execution. (Code 1979, § 21-106.18) Sec. 82-459. - Assessments after previous exemptions. (a) The city council may grant property abutting sanitary sewer lines an exemption from assessment. Often this occurs when the city, by negotiating an easement, uses private property in the laying of a sanitary sewer line. Property thus exempted can be connected to the sewerage system at any future date without being liable for assessment. (b) If, however, the property was exempted for another reason, such as the elevation of the property, and it is improved at a later date to a condition whereby sanitary sewer service can be attained and is required; then, if this occurs within 25 years after the completion of the sanitary sewer, the property is subject to assessment under provisions of this article. If the improvement occurs more than 25 years after construction, then the property may not be assessed. (Code 1979, § 21-106.20) Sec. 82-460. - Connection—By contributing consumers. (a) After sanitary sewer lines have been constructed and tied into the county sewerage system, each abutting property owner who has contributed to the costs of construction through assessment may seek a service connection. (b) To make such a connection, the property owner shall hire, at his own expense, a plumber or contractor to lay pipe from the building drain to the stub-out provided by the city. (c) Before the service line can be connected to the sanitary sewer, the owner shall secure a permit from the city by paying a plumbing fee and a sewer tap fee; provided, the service line then passes the inspection criteria of the water and wastewater department, the owner may have it connected into the sewerage system. (d) When no stub-out or other means of connection is provided so as to service the building drain, it shall be the responsibility of the water and wastewater department to provide a stub-out for the property owner at no cost. (e) Sewer contractors shall not tap any sanitary sewer mains or manholes within the jurisdiction of the department without prior authorization from the department. (Code 1979, § 21-106.21) Sec. 82-461. - Same—By noncontributing consumers. (a) When a property owner desires connection to the sewerage system within 25 years after construction of the sanitary sewer line, and he or a previous owner has not contributed to the cost of constructing the sanitary sewer line, he must pay to the water and wastewater department a proportionate cost of construction based on the footage his property abuts the sanitary sewer. After payment, the owner may construct a service line, pay a plumbing fee and a sewer tap fee, and, after the line has been inspected and approved, connect to the system. (b) If the connection is desired more than 25 years after completion of the sanitary sewer main, then there is no assessment for construction costs, and only the appropriate plumbing and sewer tap fees are paid. (Code 1979, § 21-106.21) Secs. 82-462—82-490. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - WATER AND SEWER SPECIFICATIONS FOR DEVELOPERS
Sec. 82-491. - Submission of plans required. The developer shall submit three sets of plans and specifications to the city. No work will begin until plans have been approved. (Code 1979, ch. 47(intro. ¶)) Sec. 82-492. - Sewer. (a) Pipe specifications. The following are minimum specifications for sewer pipes:
(b) Material. The following are minimum specifications for materials used in sewer construction: (1) Pipe. Pipes shall be constructed of the following: a. Polyvinyl chloride: ASTM 3034 classifications SDR 35. b. Ductile iron: Push-on joint class 350. (2) Manholes. Manholes shall be precast as per ASTM C478 with the following specifications: a. Four-foot inside diameter. b. Five-inch wall thickness. c. Plastic steps with three-eighths-inch rebar. d. Cast-iron manhole frame and cover. 1. Inside roadway 460#. 2. Outside roadways 360#. (c) Construction. Sewers to be laid in graded ditch on good material (rock or other unsatisfactory material shall be removed and good material brought in as required). Pipe shall be bedded in select material (good bank material, clay or crushed stone) well compacted. Backfill should continue with the same material, using hand tools, up to six inches above the top of the pipe. The balance of the backfill may be ditch material, providing it does not contain any large rock particles. (d) House service connections. In general, house service connections shall incline upward approximately 45 degrees above a horizontal line normal to the direction of flow in the street main. Service lines shall be laid on a straight line and grade from the sewer or riser to the property line and in no event shall service lines be less than 3½ feet deep to invert of the pipe at the property line. Where required, short radius bends shall be used to connect the service branch to the house service line. Pipe service connections together with bends, shall be placed on a compacted bed of crushed stone in such a manner as to be self-supporting and to relieve the strain on branches and bends. (1) Risers. Where trench depths are such that risers are required, service lines shall be installed by excavating into ditch bank and installing riser in a vertical position against undisturbed earth, and the entire length of the pipe containing the riser encased in concrete. Risers shall extend to the heights directed and shall be encased in a Sonotube fibre form as manufactured by Sonoco Productions Company or a brick masonry stack. Bends shall be used to connect the riser to the house service lines. (2) Stoppers, caps and plugs. All house service connections shall be closed with factory manufactured pipe stopper of such design and secured in such a manner as to not leak under a maximum hydrostatic head of ten feet or five psi air pressure. The pipe stopper shall be able to be removed without special tools, excessive force or breakage of the pipe bell. (e) Deflection testing for PVC pipe. The maximum deflection in the installed PVC pipeline shall not exceed five percent of the pipes original internal diameter. Deflection testing will be required using either a deflectometer or a "Go-no-go" mandrel. Portions of the project shall be randomly selected to be deflection tested. Such portions shall consist of not less than five percent of the total reaches (reach being length of pipe between two manholes) in the project (excluding house leads). Where deflection is found to be in excess of five percent of the original pipe diameter, the line shall be excavated to the point of excess deflection and carefully compacted and around the point where excess deflection was found. The line shall then be retested for deflection. However, should after the initial testing the deflected pipe fail to return to the original size (inside diameter) the line shall be replaced. In the event that deflection occurs beyond the five percent limit in any section of five percent or more of the reaches tested, the entire system shall be tested. (f) Testing. On completion of each block or section of sewer, sewer shall be cleaned, tested and inspected. All repairs shown necessary by the inspection shall be made. Broken or cracked pipe shall be replaced; defective joints, if any, replaced; all deposits removed, pavement replaced; and AC sewer left true to line and grade, entirely clean, free from lumps or producing jointing materials, etc., and ready for use. Each section of sewer between manholes. shall show, upon examination from either end, a reasonably full circle of light. The allowable limit of groundwater infiltration for any one or more sections of sewer with any type joint allowable under these specifications (all sizes), shall not exceed 100 gallons per 24 hours per mile of sewer line per inch of diameter. Any line that does not meet this specification will be rejected and must be repaired. No infiltration tests will be made until normal infiltration conditions are established. Tests shall be made before existing sewers are connected and measured by means of a V-notch weir.
